misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Sorting One Parallel Array Also Reorders the Other
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(scores) will sort the scores and keep each score matched with its corresponding name in the names array (i.e., that the associated names will “follow along” automatically).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort(int[]) only reorders the elements inside the scores array. It has no knowledge of the separate names array, so names is left unchanged. With parallel arrays, you must swap elements in both arrays together (e.g., custom sort loop), or sort indices/objects (e.g., create Student objects, or sort Integer indices by score) to preserve the name-score pairing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: the printed topName may not be the student who actually earned topScore (name-score mismatch).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores arrays are logically related (parallel arrays), performing a sorting operation on one array will automatically reorder the elements of the other array to maintain the original data pairings.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent objects with no inherent link to other arrays. Sorting one array (e.g., using Arrays.sort()) only modifies the indices of that specific array; it does not track or update the indices of a parallel array. To sort parallel arrays correctly, the programmer must manually implement a sort (like Bubble Sort) and perform the same swap operation on both arrays.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays stay paired after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that calling Arrays.sort(scores) will keep the names and scores aligned—either because Java will "know" that names[i] belongs with scores[i] and reorder names automatically, or because the index of the highest score after sorting (N-1) still refers to the same student in the names array.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent. Arrays.sort(scores) only permutes elements inside the scores array; it does not (and cannot, without extra code) apply the same swaps to the names array. Therefore, after sorting, names[i] and scores[i] no longer represent the same student unless you also reorder names using the exact same swap operations (or sort an array of objects/pairs).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: topScore is correct (max score), but topName is just the last-entered name, not the name that originally had that score. For the sample input, it would print "Top student: Charlie (92)" instead of "Bob (92)".

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Automatic Parallel Array Synchronization on Sort
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the `scores` array using `Arrays.sort()`, the correspondence between the `names` and `scores` arrays at each index is automatically preserved. They assume that Java somehow maintains the pairing of names[i] with scores[i] even after sorting one of the arrays.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort()` only reorders the elements within the array being sorted. It does not affect other arrays or indices. Parallel arrays are independent data structures with no inherent coupling. Once `scores` is sorted, the original index relationship is broken: names[2] is still "Charlie" but scores[2] is now 92 (which belonged to Bob at index 1 before sorting). To maintain the correspondence, the student must either (1) sort both arrays together by manually swapping elements in parallel, (2) use an index tracking mechanism, or (3) use an array of objects instead of parallel arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: The program outputs 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of the correct 'Top student: Bob (92)'. After sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the code correctly identifies that scores[2]=92 is the highest, but names[2] still points to "Charlie" (the original occupant of index 2), not "Bob" who originally had the score of 92 at index 1.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that if two arrays are intended to be 'parallel' (where elements at the same index are related), sorting one array will automatically reorder the other array to maintain those relationships.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent memory structures. The 'parallel' nature of arrays is a conceptual design choice by the programmer, not a feature of the JVM. Functions like Arrays.sort() only manipulate the specific object passed to them and have no awareness of other variables that the programmer logically associates with that data.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the link between names[i] and scores[i] is established during input and persists as a permanent bond regardless of how the elements are moved in memory.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student fails to realize that the index 'i' is the only thing linking the two pieces of data. When scores[i] is moved to a different index by a sorting algorithm, the corresponding name remains at the original index, breaking the association.
